topic: How to Make Homemade Vinegar from Fruit Scraps

sources.org: National Center for Home Food Preservation
key_facts: Vinegar must have minimum 4% acidity for canning safety
Commercial vinegar preferred for canning applications
Two-stage fermentation: sugar to alcohol, alcohol to acetic acid
Wild yeasts present on fruit skins initiate fermentation
Acetic acid is primary component giving sour taste
Vinegar production ancient method over 5000 years
Mother of vinegar contains acetobacter bacteria
pH testing recommended before use in preservation
Wild fermentation uses naturally occurring microorganisms
Organic fruits preferred to avoid pesticide inhibition

stats.stat: Vinegar production practiced for over 5,000 years
Safe canning requires at least 5% acidity (approximately pH 2.4)

quotes.quote: The key to successful fruit scrap vinegar is patience and consistent temperature. Rushing the process leads to off-flavors that no amount of aging will fix.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Kirsten Shockey
quotes.title: Fermentation Educator, Author

quotes.quote: Use organic fruit scraps when possible. Pesticide residues can inhibit the wild yeasts and bacteria essential for natural fermentation.
quotes.speaker: Sandor Katz
quotes.title: Fermentation Expert, Author of Wild Fermentation

facts.fact: 1 cup fruit scraps : 2 cups water : 2 tbsp sugar
2-4 weeks alcohol stage, 2-4 weeks vinegar stage
pH must be below 3 for proper acidity
